content:
• Monday, February 11, 2019
  • NTGR

    Netgear dips 3.2% after Amazon announces eero deal

    • Amazon.com's plan to purchase mesh networking maker eero is having an effect on at least one of eero's rivals.
    • Netgear (NASDAQ:NTGR), maker of the similarly well known Orbi equipment, is down 3.2% after hours.
    • Other makers of mesh equipment have more diverse product bases and less exposure to Amazon competition in that area.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:59 PM | 2 Comments
  • NKTR

    Nektar -5.9% as it reports urothelial cancer study

    • Nektar Therapeutics (NASDAQ:NKTR) is 5.9% lower postmarket after it reported a response rate of 48% in its study of treatment for urothelial cancer.
    • That rate means 11 of 23 patients enrolled in a study examining treatment of an NKTR-214 and Opdivo combination were evaluable for efficacy, vs. a previous 60% response rate in June. (h/t Bloomberg)
    • The company is presenting the results Friday during the American Society of Clinical Oncology Genitourinary Cancers Symposium.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:42 PM | 9 Comments
  • EA

    EA +6.2% as 'Apex Legends' crosses 25M-player mark

    • Electronic Arts (NASDAQ:EA) is capping quite a day for the stock with news that its new battle-royale title Apex Legends has surpassed 25M players in its first week and that it crested 2M concurrent players over the weekend.
    • Shares are up 6.2% after hours; they opened strong and were up as much as 9.6% early in the wake of an upgrade from BofA Merrill Lynch.
    • But those gains tailed off during the market day before the stock closed down 0.4%.
    • EA's Respawn studio says it will kick off the game's Season One in March, debuting a Battle Pass and new in-game items.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:27 PM | 12 Comments
  • VKTX

    Viking Therapeutics, Madrigal move up as Gilead liver drug fails to meet goals

    • Viking Therapeutics (NASDAQ:VKTX) +8.4% and Madrigal Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:MDGL) +3.3% after-hours as Gilead’s (NASDAQ:GILD) study designed to evaluate a chronic liver disease drug failed to meet its primary endpoint; GILD -3.6%.
    • GILD says its STELLAR-4 Phase 3 study designed to evaluate its selonsertib drug in patients with compensated cirrhosis due to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis did not meet its desired outcome without worsening the patients' condition.
    • Other companies developing therapies in liver disease include ENTA, CBAY, CNAT, GALT, AGN, SHPG, OTCPK:GNFTF, NVS.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:53 PM | 89 Comments
  • LCI

    After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: RLGT +12.5%. CHGG +9.6%. PYX +8.3%. MIME +6.3%. SBLK +5.0%.
    • Losers: VRNS -19.5%. CMP -8.8%. MGI -7.0%. OHI -5.6%. MITT -3.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:33 PM | 5 Comments
  • CMP

    Compass Minerals -9% following big Q4 earnings miss

    • Compass Minerals (NYSE:CMP) -8.8% after-hours as Q4 earnings and revenues come in well below expectations, as Q4 and full-year operating earnings fell 15% and 18%, respectively, from 2017 results.
    • Q4 Salt segment revenue rose 9% Y/Y to $284M but segment operating earnings fell 4%, as increased salt costs and lower sales volumes more than offset the benefit of increased pricing.
    • CMP says it expects Q1 earnings in its Salt segment to be limited by a Y/Y decline in North American highway deicing commitment volumes and continued cost pressures; combined with negative foreign exchange impacts on translated results for the Plant Nutrition South America segment, CMP expects Q1 consolidated EBITDA of $40M-$50M.
    • CMP forecasts FY 2019 EBITDA of $310M-$350M; the company says it will no longer provide EPS guidance ranges after determining that full-year EBITDA guidance "is the most relevant earnings metric to provide as it aligns more closely with how the company manages its businesses."
     
     
     
     
    | 5:30 PM | 13 Comments
  • OHI

    Omega Healthcare 2019 FFO midpoint trails consensus

    • Omega Healthcare Investors (NYSE:OHI) falls 3.2% in after-hours trading after introducing  2019 adjusted FFO per share guidance of $3.00-$3.12.
    • Guidance midpoint of $3.06 trails compares with consensus of $3.08.
    • Guidance assumes MedEquities acquisition occurs in Q2.
    • Also reflects revenue reduction related to Q4 asset sales and a 2019 six-month forbearance period when it will receive reduced rental payments from Daybreak, one of its operators.
    • Q4 adjusted FFO per share of 73 cents, missing consensus estimate by a penny; compares with 79 cents in the year-ago quarter.
    • Q4 total operating revenue $219.8M vs. $221.2M a year ago.
    • Challenges in the quarter included higher than normal G&A expenses, primarily related to Orianna legal expenses, and underpayment of about $4M of rent by Daybreak.
    • Conference call on Feb. 12 at 10:00 AM ET.
    • Previously: Omega Healthcare Investors misses by $0.15, beats on revenue (Feb. 11)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:14 PM | 25 Comments
  • FMC

    FMC Corp. sees flat Q1 EBITDA, earnings at low end of guidance range

    • FMC Corp. (NYSE:FMC) -1.7% after-hours as it reports better than expected Q4 earnings and a 24% Y/Y revenue increase but issues Q1 earnings guidance at the low end of Wall Street consensus.
    • For Q1, FMC forecasts EPS of $1.58-$1.68 vs. $1.67 analyst consensus estimate on revenues of $1.18B-$1.21B vs. $1.15B consensus; the company offers in-line guidance for FY 2019, seeing EPS of $5.55-$5.75, up 8% at the midpoint vs. recast 2018 earnings and in line with $5.68 consensus, and revenues of $4.45B-$4.55B vs. $4.48B consensus.
    • FMC says it agricultural solutions unit reported Q4 revenue of  ~$1.1B, up 18 Y/Y on a pro forma basis, with strong demand across all regions and higher prices in Brazil.
    • FMC says it expects "a disproportionate amount of the full-year impact from higher raw material costs and currency headwinds" during H1 2019, leading to flat Y/Y adjusted EBITDA in Q1, but it is "highly confident that we will recover all the raw material increase and a significant amount of the FX impact via price increases in all regions over the full year."
    • The company says it is set to spin off its remaining Livent (NYSE:LTHM) stake on March 1.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:11 PM
  • GILD

    Gilead's selonsertib flunks late-stage NASH study

    • Gilead Sciences (NASDAQ:GILD) is holding steady after hours on the heels of its announcement that its Phase 3 clinical trial, STELLAR-4, evaluating selonsertib in NASH patients with compensated cirrhosis failed to sufficiently separate from placebo.
    • The study failed to meet the primary endpoint of the proportion of participants achieving at least a one-stage improvement in NASH classification after 48 weeks of treatment. Specifically, 14.4% of patients receiving 18 mg of selonsertib and 12.5% of those receiving 6 mg achieved at least a one-stage improvement in NASH compared to 12.8% for placebo.
    • On the plus side, selonsertib was generally safe and well-tolerated.
    • Topline results from the Phase 3 STELLAR-3 study in NASH patients with bridging fibrosis and the Phase 2 ATLAS trial in NASH patients with advanced fibrosis should be available later this year.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:00 PM | 103 Comments
  • BRS

    Bristow Group reports preliminary Q3 results; beats by $0.51, misses on revenue

    • Bristow (NYSE:BRS): Q3 Non-GAAP EPS of -$0.57 beats by $0.51; GAAP EPS of -$2.40 misses by $2.07.
    • Revenue of $317.09M (-8.2% Y/Y) misses by $8.25M.
    • Shares +7.84%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:44 PM
  • BRS

    Bristow, Columbia Helicopters terminate takeover deal

    • Bristow (NYSE:BRS) +7.8% after-hours after agreeing to terminate its planned agreement to acquire Columbia Helicopters and to pay a $20M break-up fee.
    • BRS says "the decision to enter into a mutual termination of the purchase agreement was based on a number of developments following the entry into the agreement," but the companies are actively considering other opportunities to work together.
    • Activist investor Global Value Investment had opposed the proposed financing of the deal, saying 33M-33.5M BRS shares would be issued in order to consummate the acquisition, representing a 93% dilution.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:42 PM | 6 Comments
  • XERS

    Xeris Pharma down 5% after hours on planned equity offering

    • Xeris Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:XERS) slips 5% after hours in reaction to its planned public offering of 5M common shares. Price and terms have yet to be announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • VRNS

    Varonis -18% on downside Q1, FY19 outlook

    • Varonis Systems (NASDAQ:VRNS) plunges 18.2% after Q4 beats that came with downside Q1 and FY19 guidance.
    • Q1 forecast has revenue of $58.5M to $60M (consensus: $62.36M) and EPS of -$0.38 to -$0.36 (consensus: -$0.23).
    • FY19 guidance has revenue from $297M to $305M (consensus: $318.12M) and EPS from $0.04 to $0.16 (consensus: $0.32).
    • The company attributes the downsides to the impact from the transition to a subscription model.
    • Earnings call is scheduled for 5 PM ET with a webcast available here.
    • Press release.
    • Previously: Varonis beats by $0.20, beats on revenue (Feb. 11)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:32 PM | 3 Comments
  • MOH

    Molina Q4 top line down 6%

    • Molina Healthcare (NYSE:MOH) Q4 results ($M): Total revenue: 4,664 (-5.8%); Premiums: 4,438 (-5.4%).
    • Net income: 201 (+176.7%); non-GAAP net income: 206 (+79.8%); EPS: 3.01 (+165.6%); non-GAAP EPS: 3.07 (+67.9%); cash flow ops: (123) (+19.6%).
    • Medical cost ratio: 85.1%.
    • 2019 guidance: Total revenue: ~$16.3B; premium revenue: ~$15.8B; EPS: $9.25 - 9.75; medical care ratio: 86.7 - 87.0%;
    • Shares are up a fraction after hours.
    • Previously: Molina Healthcare beats by $1.44, beats on revenue (Feb. 11 2019)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:30 PM | 3 Comments
  • RNG

    RingCentral +4.9% after strong Q4 revenues, upbeat guidance

    • RingCentral (NYSE:RNG) is up 4.9% after hours following a Q4 beat where revenues grew by a third and the company saw healthy growth in mid-market and enterprise business.
    • The company swung to a GAAP net loss from break-even a year ago, mainly due to stock-based compensation and acquisition-related costs, and operating margin dropped to -1.8% from -0.2% for the same reasons. Non-GAAP EPS rose to $0.23 from $0.14.
    • But annualized exit monthly recurring subscriptions rose 33% to $726M; RingCentral Office ARR rose 38% to $644M; and mid-market and enterprise ARR jumped 73% to $309M. Enterprise ARR was up 99% to $171M.
    • For Q1, it's guiding to revenues of $191.5M-$194.5M (27-29% annual growth, and above consensus for $189.2M), and EPS of $0.14-$0.16 (vs. $0.14 consensus).
    • For the full year, it's guiding to revenues of $847M-$859M (26-28% annual growth, and above consensus for $823M), and EPS of $0.69-$0.73 (vs. $0.68 consensus).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Previously: RingCentral beats by $0.05, beats on revenue (Feb. 11 2019)
    • Press release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM
  • MITT

    AG Mortgage hits the capital raise button

    • AG Mortgage (NYSE:MITT) is offering 3M shares with 450K underwriter greenshoe.
    • The company this morning pre-announced a rough Q4, with book value per share falling an estimated 10.2% to $17.21. January saw a small recovery, with BVPS rising about 2%.
    • Today's close of $17.80 looks a modest premium to end-of-January book value.
    • The stock fell 2% in today's session, and is off another 1.5% after hours to $17.53.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:19 PM | 3 Comments
  • MGI

    MoneyGram -8% after light Q4 profit

    • MoneyGram International (NYSE:MGI) falls sharply after Q4 results disappoint. The company scratched out a $0.01 profit for the quarter after analysts expected EPS of $0.12.
    • Adjusted EBITDA fell 11% Y/Y to $60M during the quarter. Adjusted free cash flow was $21.1M vs. $25.7M a year ago.
    • Looking ahead, MoneyGram expects FY19 revenue growth of -4% to -2%, which has a midpoint below the consensus estimate.
    • MGI -8.5% AH.
    • Previously: MoneyGram misses by $0.11, misses on revenue (Feb. 11)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 1 Comment
  • AMKR

    Amkor -6.7% on downside guidance

    • Amkor Technology (NASDAQ:AMKR) drops 6.7% after Q4 beats with downside Q1 guidance that has revenue from $840M to $920M (consensus: $1.01B) and EPS from -$0.27 to -$0.07 (consensus: $0.03). Amkor attributes the outlook to inventory corrections underway in the smartphone market.
    • For FY19, AMKR expects capex of around $475M.
    • Earnings call is scheduled for 5 PM ET with a webcast available here.
    • Press release.
    • Previously: Amkor Technology beats by $0.11, beats on revenue (Feb. 11)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM
  • RLGT

    Radiant Logistics beats by $0.06

    • Radiant Logistics (NYSEMKT:RLGT): Q2 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.16 beats by $0.06; GAAP EPS of $0.07 misses by $0.03.
    • Revenue of $260.94M (+26.2% Y/Y)
    • Shares +2.95%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM
  • CHGG

    Chegg beats by $0.04, beats on revenue

    • Chegg (NYSE:CHGG): Q4 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.25 beats by $0.04; GAAP EPS of $0.04 in-line.
    • Revenue of $95.67M (+30.1% Y/Y) beats by $4.07M.
    • Shares +7.79%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM | 5 Comments
  • CHGG

    Chegg beats by $0.04, beats on revenue

    • Chegg (NYSE:CHGG): Q4 Non-GAAP EPS of $0.25 beats by $0.04; GAAP EPS of $0.04 in-line.
    • Revenue of $95.67M (+30.1% Y/Y) beats by $4.07M.
    • Shares +7.79%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM
  • TSLA

    T. Rowe Price a big seller of Tesla

    • T Rowe Price Group reduced its position in Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) to 8.98M shares at the end of Q4, according to a new filing.
    • The fund manager held 17.4M shares at the end of Q3.
    • The selling by T. Rowe during the quarter reduced its ownership stake in Tesla to 5.2%.
    • Shares of Tesla ended the day up 2.30% to $312.84.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:05 PM | 175 Comments
  • GCI

    MNG rebuts characterization of meeting with Gannett

    • The latest in what's becoming an increasingly hostile back-and-forth over a proposal to acquire Gannett (GCI -2.1%) comes from suitor MNG, who responds to today's Gannett note by reiterating the company can't achieve its bid value on its own.
    • “Gannett grossly mischaracterized the meeting we had last week, as well as MNG’s ability to close this transaction," MNG says in its reply. "MNG expects to have fully committed financing in place within weeks, and the pro forma leverage profile of the combined companies would be very conservative relative to industry comparables. Further, MNG can complete its diligence within four weeks with the cooperation of Gannett."
    • Under the watch of Chairman Jeff Louis, Gannett has seen adjusted EBITDA decline 31% and free cash flow by 50%, MNG says.
    • It's offering $12/share in cash, while Gannett is at $10.92.
    • MNG has a 7.5% stake in Gannett.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM | 3 Comments
  • CPRX

    Net price of Catalyst Pharma's Firdapse to be $300K+ per year

    • Catalyst Pharmaceuticals (CPRX +2.4%) says that the net price per year for LEMS med Firdapse (amifampridine) will be $300K - 318,750 per year, representing about a 15 - 20% discount off the $375K list price. The net price includes rebates to insurers and other discounts.
    • The discount, whatever it will be, means little to LEMS patients since they were previously getting it for free from New Jersey-based Jacobus Pharmaceuticals under the FDA's compassionate use program.
    • On cue, Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT) has sent a letter to the company asking it to justify the price.
    • Catalyst acquired the rights to the drug from BioMarin Pharmaceutical in 2012.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:39 PM | 8 Comments
  • ALE

    Allete -3% as Mizuho downgrades following water services sale

    • Allete (ALE -3.1%) turns sharply lower from its highest levels in two months after Mizuho downgrades shares to Underperform and trims its price target to $72 from $74, saying the company will face additional execution pressure on its remaining business segments following its decision to sell its U.S. Water Services business.
    • Mizuho analyst Paul Fremont believes ALE will need to "fill the earnings gap" with investments at the Ace segment and/or the regulated subsidiary in order to maintain its 5%-7% annual growth guidance.
    • The firm also thinks ALE will miss on the midpoint of its fiscal 2018 guidance due to weak equipment sales.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 3 Comments

  • Theater stocks tumble after Lego movie fails to deliver

    • A disastrous opening for The Lego Movie 2 is hitting the exhibitor sector hard today.
    • The Warner Bros. film only brought in $34.4M in the U.S. during the weekend to trail expectations for around $50M. There was some hope going into the weekend that the Lego installment would help turn around the slow start to the post-holiday movie season.
    • After taking in the response of moviegoers, B. Riley lowers its estimate for Q1 U.S. box office sales growth to -12.2% from a prior estimate of -10.5%.
    • Cinemark (CNK -5%), AMC Entertainment (AMC -4.7%), Marcus Corporation (MCS -2.1%), IMAX (IMAX -2.6%) and National CineMedia (NCMI -5%) are all notably lower in U.S. trading - while Cineplex (OTCPK:CPXGF) is down 2.7% in Toronto trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:07 PM | 21 Comments
  • ZAYO

    Zayo heads lower on report of lower private-equity bid

    • Zayo Group (NYSE:ZAYO) has moved into negative ground, now down 4.3%, after a CTFN report says a revised offer for the company has come in lower than the last one.
    • The latest bid is now for about $30/share, according to the report.
    • That's below what chatter had as a bid in the low- to mid-$30s late last month.
    • Shares are currently at $25.12, down $1.19.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:02 PM | 5 Comments

  • Microcaps tops tech movers

    • Gainers: SPI Energy (NASDAQ:SPI) +43%. SilverSun Technologies (NASDAQ:SSNT) +31%. CLPS Incorporation (NASDAQ:CLPS) +27%. Creative Realities (NASDAQ:CREX) +24%. CounterPath (NASDAQ:CPAH) +21%.
    • Losers: Kopin Corporation (NASDAQ:KOPN) -18%. Professional Diversity Network (NASDAQ:IPDN) -11%. The Meet Group (NASDAQ:MEET) -10%. QuinStreet (NASDAQ:QNST) -10%. GrubHub (NYSE:GRUB) -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:57 PM
  • AR

    Antero Resources, DoJ reach settlement for Clean Water Act violations

    • The Department of Justice says it reached a settlement with Antero Resources (AR +2.2%) over claims the company violated the Clean Water Act at 32 different sites in West Virginia, mostly tied to fracking.
    • AR agrees to pay a $3.15M penalty and provide mitigation and restoration of affected sites, estimated to cost $8M, related to violations involving unauthorized disposal of materials into local waterways through fracking, the DoJ says.
    • AR identified roughly half of the sites through its own self-audit, the DoJ says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:54 PM

  • FTS International and Forum Energy Technologies among Energy/Materials gainers; Mountain Province Diamonds and Amyris among losers

    • Gainers: FTS International (NYSE:FTSI) +13%. Forum Energy Technologies (NYSE:FET) +11%. VAALCO Energy (NYSE:EGY) +9%. Range Resources (NYSE:RRC) +8%. Ferrellgas Partners (NYSE:FGP) +7%.
    • Losers: Mountain Province Diamonds (NYSEMKT:MPVD) -12%. Amyris (NASDAQ:AMRS) -8%. Diamond Offshore Drilling (NYSE:DO) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM
  • WETF

    WisdomTree explored a sale late last year: Bloomberg

    • WisdomTree (WETF +5.9%) explored a sale late last year and held talks with JPMorgan Chase (JPM -0.1%), but negotiations fell apart when they couldn't agree on a price as WETF's shares sank during the December market turmoil, Bloomberg reports, citing people familiar with the matter.
    • The asset manager isn't currently pursuing a sale, they said.
    • WETF shares rose as much as 7.2% today; since the end of November, WisdomTree fell about 16% to close at $5.97 on Friday, Feb. 8, 2019.
    • Previously: WisdomTree -6% as AUM slips, advisory fee rate shrinks (Feb. 1)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:55 PM | 2 Comments

  • Citi replaces Top Pick Nvidia

    • Citi lowers its Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) price target from $244 to $200 and replaces the company with Marvell (NASDAQ:MRVL) as its Top Pick.
    • Late last month, Nvidia cut its Q4 revenue guidance on weaker than expected sales of its gaming and datacenter platforms.
    • Previously: Bernstein downgardes Nvidia on increasing headline risk (Feb. 11)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:53 PM | 13 Comments
  • VRTHF

    Veritas Pharma advancing presence in Puerto Rico

    • Veritas Pharma (OTCPK:VRTHF) announces that the Puerto Rico Medicinal Cannabis Regulatory Board has signed off on an Investigation License allowing the clinical evaluation of lead cannabis product CTL-X for relieving acute pain. The company is developing the candidate in collaboration with the Institute for Medicinal Cannabis and the Fundacion de Investigacion, Puerto Rico's leading medical cannabis researchers.
    • A three-month clinical trial should commence this week.
    • Shares are up 2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:39 PM
  • TENB

    Tenable +2% on Buy initiation

    • Summit Insights starts Tenable (NASDAQ:TENB) with a Buy rating and $35 target, a 27% upside.
    • Earlier this month, Tenable reported Q4 results that featured 39% Y/Y revenue growth. Q1 guidance includes upside revenue from $77.5M to $78.5M and in-line EPS from -$0.19 to -$0.18.
    • Upside FY19 guidance has revenue of $338M to $343M and EPS from -$0.62 to -$0.57.
    • Tenable shares are up 2.4% to $27.64.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:34 PM
  • FND

    Gordon Haskett cautious on Floor & Decor

    • Floor & Decor (FND -0.6%) slips after Gordon Haskett downgrades the retailer to a Hold rating from Accumulate.
    • The firm cools off on Floor & Decor after accounting for the 24% YTD share price gain in the face of an outlook for a weaker overall macro housing landscape.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:30 PM
  • CBS

    CBS lower after cut to Neutral at Atlantic Equities

    • CBS (CBS -2.5%) has seen a downgrade to Neutral at Atlantic Equities.
    • The firm trimmed its recommendation from Overweight, departing from a majority-bulllish Street.
    • It's cut its price target to $56 from $67, implying 16% upside from current pricing.
    • A decent start to 2019 took the edge off what's now a three-month price decline of 14.2%; shares are up 13.4% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:18 PM
  • ENOB

    Enochian Bio up 19% on investor update

    • Thinly traded micro cap Enochian Biosciences (OTCQB:ENOB +19.2%) is up on more than double normal volume, albeit on turnover of only 90K shares, ahead of today's investor event.
    • The company's pipeline includes preventative and therapeutic HIV vaccines and dendritic cell vaccines for cancer.
    • On the working capital front, at the end of September, it had $13.4M in cash while operations consumed $1.8M during the quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:01 PM | 1 Comment

  • China Bat Group among financial gainers and CNA Financial among losers

    • Gainers: China Bat Group (NASDAQ:GLG) +6%. Great Elm Capital Group (NYSE:GEC) +5%.
    • Losers: Mercury General (NYSE:MCY) -7%. CNA Financial (NYSE:CNA) -6%. Loews (NYSE:L) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM

  • Microcaps dominate midday movers

    • Gainers: SPI Energy (NASDAQ:SPI) +45%. SilverSun Technologies (NASDAQ:SSNT) +30%. Proteostasis Therapeutics (NASDAQ:PTI) +26%. Enochian Biosciences (OTCQB:ENOB) +20%. Nemaura Medical (NASDAQ:NMRD) +19%. Select Interior Concepts (NASDAQ:SIC) +18%. Replimune Group (NASDAQ:REPL) +15%. Insperity (NYSE:NSP) +15%. NuVasive (NASDAQ:NUVA) +15%. SCYNEXIS (NASDAQ:SCYX) +14%.
    • Losers: Fuling Global (NASDAQ:FORK) -19%. Professional Diversity Network (NASDAQ:IPDN) -19%. Kopin (NASDAQ:KOPN) -16%. Mustang Bio (NASDAQ:MBIO) -15%. Celldex Therapeutics (NASDAQ:CLDX) -14%. Riot Blockchain (NASDAQ:RIOT) -14%. TMSR Holding Company (NASDAQ:TMSR) -11%. NantKwest (NASDAQ:NK) -11%. The Meet Group (NASDAQ:MEET) -11%. Mountain Province Diamonds (NYSEMKT:MPVD) -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM
  • CELG

    Celgene prevails in Revlimid patent challenge from Dr. Reddy's

    • The USPTO has declined to sign off on an inter partes review of Celgene's (CELG +2.1%) U.S. Patent No. 8,404,717 covering top seller Revlimid, requested by would-be generic competitor Dr. Reddy's Laboratories (RDY -5.1%).
    • The USPTO will decide on two additional patents, No. 9,056,120 and No. 7,189,740, any day.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:33 PM | 13 Comments
  • NMRD

    Nemaura Medical up 20% ahead of U.S. application for sugarBEAT CGM

    • Thinly traded micro cap Nemaura Medical (NMRD +20.4%) is up up almost a 10x surge in volume. No particular news accounts for the action but the company expects to file a U.S. marketing application this quarter for continuous glucose monitor (CGM) sugarBEAT.
    • On Friday, February 8, it filed an 8-K disclosing that CFO Iain Anderson resigned effective immediately. President & CEO Dewan Chowdhury has assumed his duties on an interim basis until a permanent successor is on board.
    • In mid-December, it filed a prospectus supplement for an offer of 2.4M common shares and accompanying five-year warrants to purchase up to the same number of shares at $1.04 per share and warrant to placement agent Dawson James Securities who will use its "best efforts" to resell the equity.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:13 PM | 1 Comment

  • Avon Products and The Lovesac Company consumer gainers; Fuling Global leads the losers

    • Gainers: The Lovesac Company (NASDAQ:LOVE) +8%. Avon Products (NYSE:AVP) +6%.
    • Losers: Fuling Global (NASDAQ:FORK) -19%. Natuzzi (NYSE:NTZ) -8%. Fuwei Films (NASDAQ:FFHL) -7%.

  • SCCO

    Peru authorities probe possible tailings dam spill at Southern Copper mine

    • Peru’s environmental watchdog says it is investigating a potential tailings spill from Southern Copper's (SCCO -2%) Cuajone mine into a river in an area that has been inundated by heavy rains.
    • The authority says it detected a "flow of a greenish solution" starting Friday into the nearby Torata River in the waste deposit area of the operation; the spill apparently stopped yesterday.
    • SCCO says it shut down the processing plant at Cuajone as a preventative measure on Friday but believes there was no tailings spill.
    • Some areas in northern Chile have suffered the highest levels of rainfall in 40-plus years, leaving six people dead, and neighboring Chile, the world's top copper producer, also has suspended some copper operations due to unusual rainfall.
    • If a spill at Cuajone actually occurred, SCCO could see renewed opposition to its $1.4B Tia Maria project, which has been stalled for years amid communities' concerns over the potential impact on water and air quality.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:50 AM | 2 Comments
  • CCJ

    Cameco says improved uranium market not enough to warrant new supply

    • Cameco (CCJ +0.3%) warns against investing in new uranium mines, saying "even the promise" of new supply could create a headwind and place downward pressure on uranium prices.
    • "There is plenty of idle tier one production and tier one expansion capabilities, as well as idle tier two production and expansion capabilities," CCJ says. "And we can't lose sight of material sitting with financial players. This is capacity that can come back to the market relatively quickly. As a result, new supply poses a significant risk to the uranium market recovery."
    • CCJ says interest in long-term contracting has returned, but prices and contracting opportunities are not where they should be to restart idled capacity or warrant investment in growth opportunities.
    • The company also says the possibility of Section 232 U.S. tariffs on uranium imports is still creating uncertainty.
    • Shares are slightly higher after reporting better than expected Q4 earnings while saying 2019 gross margin could come in weaker.

  • USO

    Crude oil slumps on stronger dollar, U.S.-China worries, rising U.S. rig count

    • Crude oil prices slide near four-week lows due to a stronger dollar and continued concerns about U.S.-China trade talks; WTI -2.1% to $51.59/bbl, Brent -1.3% at $61.31/bbl.
    • Despite the drop in crude, the Energy Select SPDR (XLE +0.1%) is posting a small gain; USO -2.4%.
    • "The U.S. dollar is strengthening again today in spurring much of today’s early WTI weakness," according to analysts at Ritterbusch and Associates. "WTI appeared much more willing to follow equities lower than higher last week with the strength in the U.S. dollar evolving as the decider in pushing WTI values back to below our expected $53 support."
    • "Oil prices are still trying to figure out what lead to follow," says Vienna-based consultancy JBC Energy. "On the one hand, there is the OPEC+ cut story, now coupled with increasing issues around Venezuelan supply. [But] it has to be argued that a lot of the economic data that has been released over the last few days has really not been too encouraging, and U.S.-Chinese trade talks are also seemingly not progressing very fast."
    • Also, the U.S. oil rig count jumped last week and there are "rumors that Venezuela is trying to skirt U.S. sanctions by means of trade with India," says RJO Futures senior market strategist John Caruso. "More downside in coming weeks is our forecast," but with WTI likely holding the $49-$48 area.
    • ETFs: USO, XLE, OIL, UWT, UCO, VDE, XOP, DWT, ERX, OIH, SCO, BNO, DBO, ERY, DIG, BGR, GUSH, DTO, FENY, USL, IYE, DUG, DRIP, IEO, FIF, DNO, NDP, PXE, OLO, RYE, PXJ, SZO, CRAK, FXN, OLEM, WTIU, DDG, OILK, NANR, OILX, WTID, USOI, USOU, USOD, FTXN, JHME, OILD, OILU, USAI
